document.masterDocTitle: A review of Combretum falcatum (Welw. ex Hiern) Jongkind (Combretaceae) and related species from Africa, including Combretum baldwinii Jongkind, sp. nov., from Nigeria

FIG. 5. —
Combretum mussaendiflorum Engl. & Diels
, note the red leaves around the inflorescence and the bristle like hairs on the brachlets. Photo: Ruud de Block, 10th May 2016, in the large Greenhouse of Botanic Garden Meise.

FIG. 6. —
Combretum falcatum (Welw.ex Hiern) Jongkind. N.Texier et al.2254
. Photo:Nicolas Texier.

FIG. 7. — Geographic distribution of
Combretum falcatum (Welw. ex Hiern) Jongkind
(●) and
Combretum littoreum (Engler) Engler & Diels
(▴)

subSubSection.paragraph:
DISTRIBUTION AND ECOLOGY. —
Combretum pellegrinianum
is found in between the large closed forest areas of Gabon in the west and Congo Kinshasa in the east, in an area with an often more open vegetation with savanna and gallery forest ( Fig. 4A ). It differs in ecology from the related
C. mussaendiflorum
that is only found in the (originally) closed forest in the east of Congo Kishasa.

Quisqualis pellegriniana Keay (1954: 275)
, Talbot 498 (BM), represents
Griffonia physocarpa Baill.
